column1: Angoche is a city of Nampula Province in Mozambique. The city was named António Enes until 1976
column2: after the 19th-century Portuguese journalist and colonial administrator
column3: António José Enes. In administrative terms
column5: the city is also a municipality.

column1: Angoche is an old Muslim trading centre
column2: which local tradition states was founded in the 1490s by refugees from the Kilwa Sultanate. Xosa
column3: the son of one of the leaders of the refugees
column4: was made the first sultan. One of the earliest settlements in Mozambique and an important gold and ivory trading post
column5: it posed a serious rival to the Portuguese settlement in Mozambigue until the mid-16th century
column6: when Angoche was eclipsed by Quelimane as an entry port to the interior. However
column7: Angoche continued to play a role in coastal trade and was an important economic and political centre in the region
column8: with close ties to Ilha de Moçambique. In the 19th century
column9: Angoche became the focus of the clandestine slave trade
column10: which continued until the 1860s when the town was attacked by the Portuguese. While effective Portuguese administration was not established until several decades later
column11: the attack marked the beginning of Angoche's downfall
column12: and the town never regained its former status.Today
column14: somewhat dilapidated district capital with few reminders of its past.  Several islands lie offshore from the town. The major language of Angoche and nearby Koti Island is Ekoti
column15: a Makhuwa language borrowing from 15th century Swahili.
